sen.j: 公家（くげ）とは、日本において朝廷に仕える貴族・官人の総称。
sen.e: Kuge is a general term to refer to nobles and government officials who serve chotei (Imperial Court) in Japan.
sen.cmt: テーマが「公家」ですので「朝廷」が合計4回でてきます。7欄の「朝家」についてはローマ字になっていますので、ここでもchoteiとしました。
sen.e: Kuge is a general term to refer to nobles and government officials who serve chotei (Imperial Court) in Japan.
Kuge is a general term to refer to nobles and government officials who serve chotei (Imperial Court) in Japan.

sen.j: 元来は天皇または朝廷を指し、「こうけ」「おおやけ」と読んだ。
sen.e: Originally it meant Emperor or chotei and read 'koke' (public family) or 'oyake' (public or official).
Originally it meant Emperor or chotei and read 'koke' (public family) or 'oyake' (public or official).
Originally it meant Emperor or chotei and read 'koke' (public family) or 'oyake' (public or official).

sen.j: 鎌倉時代以降、武力で朝家に奉仕する幕府を武家と称するようになると、それに対比して、政務一般をもって朝家に奉仕する貴族一般を公家と呼ぶようになった。
sen.e: Since the Kamakura period, bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) which served choka (the imperial family or household) with military power was refered to as buke (samural family), on the other hand, nobles who served choka in governmental affairs came to be called kuge.
sen.cmt: ここでは武家（buke）が公家（kuge）と対になって使われていますので、buke(samurai family)のままにしました。
sen.e: Since the Kamakura period, bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) that served choka (the imperial family or household) with military power was refered to as buke (samural family), nobles who served choka in governmental affairs came to be called kuge.

Since the Kamakura period, bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) that served choka (the imperial family or household) with military power was refered to as buke (samural family), nobles who served choka in governmental affairs came to be called kuge.

sen.j: 平安時代末期ごろから貴族社会において公卿に昇る家柄が限定されるようになり、藤原北家による摂家の確立に伴って家格が固定化し、鎌倉時代前期ごろまでに公家社会が形成された。
sen.e: In the aristocratic society family lineage which allowed one to ascend to Kugyo (the top court officials) began to be limited since the late Heian period, and as kakaku (family status) was fixed when Sekke (line of regents and advisers) was established by the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, a hierarchical kuge society was formed by the early Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: 日本語には「階級性の」という語はありませんが、「家格が固定し」たことと「公家社会が形成された」ことの繋がりがわかりにくいので、hierarchical kuge societyという言葉を足しました。後列にもそれに関連することがでてきます。
sen.e: In the aristocratic society family lineage which allowed one to ascend to Kugyo (the top court officials) began to be limited since the late Heian period, and as kakaku (family status) was fixed when Sekke (line of regents and advisers) was established by the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, a hierarchical kuge society was formed by the early Kamakura period.

In the aristocratic society family lineage which allowed one to ascend to Kugyo (the top court officials) began to be limited since the late Heian period, and as kakaku (family status) was fixed when Sekke (line of regents and advisers) was established by the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, a hierarchical kuge society was formed by the early Kamakura period.

sen.j: 公家社会においては、家格によって昇進できる官職が定まっていた。
sen.e: In the kuge society, the highest government post one could reach depended on one's kakaku.
In the kuge society, the highest government post one could reach depended on one's kakaku.
In the kuge society, the highest government post one could reach depended on one's kakaku.

sen.j: この当時、日本の社会各層で家産の相続を前提とする「家」（イエ）制度の成立が進行しており、公家社会の形成も、貴族層における「家」の成立として理解することができる。
sen.e: At that time 'a family system' assuming inheritance of family property was being established in each class of the Japanese society, therefore, the formation of the kuge society can be understood as establishment of 'a family' in the noble hierarchy.

At that time 'a family system' assuming inheritance of family property was being established in each class of Japanese society, therefore, the formation of the kuge society can be understood as establishment of 'a family' within the noble hierarchy.

At that time 'a family system' assuming inheritance of family property was being established in each class of Japanese society, therefore, the formation of the kuge society can be understood as establishment of 'a family' within the noble hierarchy.

sen.j: 成立期の公家の経済的基盤は、荘園・公領に対する収取権であった。
sen.e: The finacial basis of kuge in its formative period depended on the right to collect land tax from shoen (manor) and koryo (public land).
sen.cmt: 「収取権」という意味が何を収取するのかが書かれていませんが、「年貢」（land tax）を補いました。「年貢」：http://kotobank.jp/word/%E5%B9%B4%E8%B2%A2
sen.e: The finacial basis of kuge in its formative period depended on the right to collect land tax from shoen (manor) and koryo (public land).
The finacial basis of kuge in its formative period depended on the right to collect land tax from shoen (manor) and koryo (public land).

sen.j: 公家のうち、上流貴族は荘園寄進を受けて本家として荘園支配を行うことにより、また中流貴族は上流貴族や大寺社から預所などに任命されて荘園管理権を得ることにより、経済的基盤を築いていた。
sen.e: Among the kuge, the upper nobles were building up their financial basis by ruling a shoen estate as honke (a head family), gaining the commendation of shoen, and middle-class nobles were doing so by gaining the right to manage shoen, as they were appointed to azukaridokoro (a deputy of "shoen" manor lord) by upper nobles or main temples and shrines, and so on

Among the kuge, the upper nobles were building up their financial basis by ruling a shoen estate as honke (a head family), gaining the commendation of shoen, and middle-class nobles were doing so by gaining the right to manage shoen, as they were appointed to azukaridokoro (a deputy of "shoen" manor lord) by upper nobles or main temples and shrines, and so on

Among the kuge, the upper nobles were building up their financial basis by ruling a shoen estate as honke (a head family), gaining the commendation of shoen, and middle-class nobles were doing so by gaining the right to manage shoen, as they were appointed to azukaridokoro (a deputy of "shoen" manor lord) by upper nobles or main temples and shrines, and so on

sen.j: 鎌倉時代を通じ、主に軍事警察権と東国支配を担当する武家政権（鎌倉幕府）に相対して、政務一般と西国支配を所掌する公家政権（朝廷）が存在しており、両政権がおおむね協調連携しながら政務にあたっていた。
sen.e: Throughout the Kamakura period, not only the military government (Kamakura bakufu) which mainly took charge of military and police authorities and the dominion of Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region), but also the kuge government (chotei) which dealt with governmental affairs and ruling of Seigoku (the western part of Japan) co-existed, and the both attended to government in cooporation.

Throughout the Kamakura period, not only the military government (Kamakura bakufu) which mainly took charge of military and police authorities and the dominion of Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly the Kanto region), but also the kuge government (chotei) which dealt with governmental affairs and ruling of Seigoku (the western part of Japan) co-existed, and the both attended the government in cooporation.

Throughout the Kamakura period, not only the military government (Kamakura bakufu) which mainly took charge of military and police authorities and the dominion of Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly the Kanto region), but also the kuge government (chotei) which dealt with governmental affairs and ruling of Seigoku (the western part of Japan) co-existed, and the both attended the government in cooporation.

sen.j: ただし、在地レベルでは公家側の経済的支配権が、現地の武士（地頭）らに侵食されるケースが現れ始めていた。
sen.e: In local areas, however, some cases where the rights of the kuge side to financial control were encroached by local samurai (jito) (manager and lord of manor) began to appear.
In local areas, however, some cases where the rights of the kuge side to financial control were encroached by local samurai (jito) (manager and lord of manor) began to appear.
In local areas, however, some cases where the rights of the kuge side to financial control were encroached by local samurai (jito) (manager and lord of manor) began to appear.

sen.j: この傾向は、室町時代に至って顕著となる。
sen.e: This inclination became evident in the Muromachi period.
This inclination became evident during the Muromachi period.
This inclination became evident during the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 公家政権の権限は、幕府および守護によって大きく侵されてされていき、次第に有名無実化していった。
sen.e: The authority of the kuge government came to be greatly encroached by the bakufu and shugo (provincial constable), and gradually became little more than a mere name.
The authority of the kuge government came to be greatly encroached by the bakufu and shugo (provincial constable), and gradually became little more than a mere name.
The authority of the kuge government came to be greatly encroached by the bakufu and shugo (provincial constable), and gradually became little more than a mere name.

sen.j: 江戸時代に入ると、公家社会は幕府から保護を受けることとなったが、反面、天皇と公家を規制する禁中並公家諸法度が定められ、これにより江戸時代の公武関係が規定された。
sen.e: In the Edo period, the kuge society gained protection from the bakufu, while the "Kinchu narabini kuge shohatto" (a set of legal regulations that applied to emperors and Kyoto nobles) which regulated emperors and kuge was established and defined relationship between kuge and samurai of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 禁中並公家諸法度：江戸時代を通して続いた法律とありますので、regulationsの前にlegalを付け加え、emperorを複数にしました。 reguhttp://kotobank.jp/word/%E7%A6%81%E4%B8%AD%E4%B8%A6%E5%85%AC%E5%AE%B6%E8%AB%B8%E6%B3%95%E5%BA%A6
sen.e: During the Edo period, the kuge society gained protection from the bakufu, while the "Kinchu narabini kuge shohatto" (a set of legal regulations that applied to emperors and Kyoto nobles) that regulated emperors and kuge was established and defined the relationship between kuge and samurai of the Edo period.

During the Edo period, the kuge society gained protection from the bakufu, while the "Kinchu narabini kuge shohatto" (a set of legal regulations that applied to emperors and Kyoto nobles) that regulated emperors and kuge was established and defined the relationship between kuge and samurai of the Edo period.

sen.j: 公家社会は幕末まで温存されたが、明治維新期に解体され、公家のほとんどは華族身分へ移行した。
sen.e: Although the kuge society was retained until the end of the Edo period, it was abolished in the course of the Meiji Restoration and most of the kuge shifted to the social status of peerage.
Although the kuge society was retained until the end of the Edo period, it was abolished in the course of the Meiji Restoration and most of the kuge shifted to the social status of peerage.
Although the kuge society was retained until the end of the Edo period, it was abolished in the course of the Meiji Restoration and most of the kuge shifted to the social status of peerage.

sen.j: 幕末には朝廷権力の復活を背景に岩倉具視や三条実美など明治維新に功績を残した者を多数輩出した。
sen.e: At the end of the Edo period, with a background of revival of chotei's authority, it produced many important figures, such as Tomomi IWAKURA and Sanemi SANJO who left great achievements to the Meiji Restoration,

At the end of the Edo period, with the background of a revival of chotei's authority, it produced many important figures, such as Tomomi IWAKURA and Sanemi SANJO who left great achievements during the Meiji Restoration,

At the end of the Edo period, with the background of a revival of chotei's authority, it produced many important figures, such as Tomomi IWAKURA and Sanemi SANJO who left great achievements during the Meiji Restoration.
sen.cmt: 文末をコンマ→ピリオド

sen.j: 公家は、広い意味では殿上人が許された家である堂上家と許されていない地下家の2つに分けられるが、一般的に公家と言えば堂上家を指す。
sen.e: Kuge can be classified into two ranks in a broader sense - "Toshoke" (the hereditary lineage of court nobles occupying relatively high ranks) which refers to a family allowed to be tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) and Jigeke (family status of non-noble retainers who are not allowed into the Emperor's living quarters in the Imperial Palace) which refers to a family otherwise, but generally speaking, kuge refers to Toshoke.
sen.cmt: ここではImperial Palaceがカッコ内の説明として2回ありますが、それぞれが大文字と小文字になっていました。ここでは大文字で統一しました。下のImperial Courtも同様に大文字にしました。前列の朝廷の説明が大文字になっていましたので。
sen.e: Kuge can be classified into two ranks in a broader sense - "Toshoke" (the hereditary lineage of court nobles occupying relatively high ranks) which refers to a family allowed to be tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) and Jigeke (family status of non-noble retainers who are not allowed into the Emperor's living quarters in the Imperial Palace) which refers to a family otherwise, but generally speaking, kuge refers to Toshoke.

Kuge can be classified into two ranks in a broader sense - "Toshoke" (the hereditary lineage of court nobles occupying relatively high ranks) which refers to a family allowed to be tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) and Jigeke (family status of non-noble retainers who are not allowed into the Emperor's living quarters in the Imperial Palace) which refers to a family otherwise, but generally speaking, kuge refers to Toshoke.

sen.j: 昇殿が許された堂上家および殿上人を公家と呼ぶ慣わしは、江戸時代まで継続している。
sen.e: Such tradition to call Toshoke and tenjobito which are allowed to access to the Imperial Court 'kuge' continued to the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 「昇殿が許された」ですが、ここでは「堂上家および殿上人」の両方にかかると解釈し、「公家と呼ぶ」を'kuge'として引用符で囲みました。
sen.e: Such tradition to call Toshoke and tenjobito which are allowed access to the Imperial Court 'kuge' continued to the Edo period.
Such tradition to call Toshoke and tenjobito which were allowed access to the Imperial Court 'kuge' continued to the Edo period.

sen.j: また、古くからある家は旧家、安土桃山時代以降に分家し新たに創設された家は、新家と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Besides, a family which dated back generations ago was called kyuka (old family), and those which moved out and set up a new branch family after the Azuchi-Momoyama period was called sinke (newly founded family).
sen.cmt: ここでは「旧家」、「新家」をローマ字にし、その説明を英語で括弧にいれました。
sen.e: Besides, a family dated back generations ago was called kyuka (old family), and those which moved out and set up a new branch family after the Azuchi-Momoyama period were called sinke (newly founded family).

Besides, a family dated back generations ago was called kyuka (old family), and those which moved out and set up a new branch family after the Azuchi-Momoyama period were called shinke (newly founded family).

sen.j: 平安末期から鎌倉時代にかけて公家の家格が固定化され、家柄によって昇進できる官職が限定された。
sen.e: Between the late Heian period and the Kamakura period, kakaku of the kuge was fixed and government posts one could attain were restricted depending on one's lineage and pedigree.
Between the late Heian period and the Kamakura period, kakaku of the kuge was fixed and the government posts one could attain were restricted depending on one's lineage and pedigree.
Between the late Heian period and the Kamakura period, kakaku of the kuge was fixed and the government posts one could attain were restricted depending on one's lineage and pedigree.

sen.j: この時期、以下の序列のとおりの家格が形成された。
sen.e: During this period kakuku was formulated in the following order.
During this period kakuku was formulated in the following order.
During this period kakuku was formulated in the following order.

sen.j: （詳細は各項目を参照。)
sen.e: (See each item for details.)
(See each item for details.)
(See each item for details.)

sen.j: 摂家
sen.e: Sekke (line of regents and advisers).
Sekke (line of regents and advisers).
Sekke (line of regents and advisers)

sen.j: 清華家
sen.e: Seiga family (one of the highest court noble families in Japan at that time).
Seiga family (one of the highest court noble families in Japan at that time).
Seiga family (one of the highest court noble families in Japan at that time)

sen.j: 大臣家
sen.e: The house of minister.
The house of the minister.
The house of minister
sen.cmt: 文末のピリオド削除The house of the minister→The house of minister

sen.j: 羽林家
sen.e: The House of Urin (holding military ranks).
The House of Urin (holding military ranks).
The House of Urin (holding military ranks)

sen.j: 名家 (公家)
sen.e: Important noble family (kuge).
Important noble family (kuge).
Important noble family (kuge)

sen.j: 半家 (公家)（諸大夫）
sen.e: Hanke (a kind of family status of the court nobles) (kuge) (shodaibu) (aristocracy lower than Kugyo).
Hanke (a kind of family status of court nobles) (kuge) (shodaibu) (aristocracy lower than Kugyo).
Hanke (a kind of family status of court nobles) (kuge) (shodaibu) (aristocracy lower than Kugyo)

sen.j: 華族への移行に当たっては、公家出身の家は公家時代の家格と代々の任官状況で華族としての地位を取り決められた。
sen.e: In the course of transition to the peerage, status as the peerage of kuge families was decided according to their kakaku and the record of appointments in generations while they served their governments.
In the course of transition to peerage, status as peerage of kuge families was decided according to their kakaku and the record of appointments in generations while they served their governments.
In the course of transition to peerage, status as peerage of kuge families was decided according to their kakaku and the record of appointments in generations while they served their governments.

sen.j: おもに摂家や清華家の当主を公爵家・侯爵家とし、それ以下の家においては大納言を多く輩出した家を伯爵家、そうでない家を子爵家としている。
sen.e: In principle, heads of Sekke and Seiga family became Dukes or Marquises, families whose ranks are below them became earls if they had produced many Dainagon (chief of the councilor of State), and otherwise they became viscounts.

In principle, heads of Sekke and Seiga family became Dukes or Marquises, families whose ranks were below them became earls if they had produced many Dainagon (chief of the councilor of State), and otherwise they became viscounts.

In principle, heads of Sekke and Seiga family became Dukes or Marquises, families whose ranks were below them became earls if they had produced many Dainagon (chief of the councilor of State), and otherwise they became viscounts.

sen.j: また地下家のうち華族となった家はすべて男爵家へ移行している。
sen.e: In addition, some of the jika families, which became the peerage, all shifted to the barons.
In addition, some of the jika families, that became peerage, all shifted to barons.
In addition, some of the jika families, that became peerage, all shifted to barons.
